summary: This is the November 2020 Executive Summary of the Department of Justice Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) report investigating the conduct of prosecutors in the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida regarding the 2006-2008 federal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. It examines the negotiation and execution of the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) and the office's interactions with victims, concluding the prosecutors did not commit professional misconduct but exercised poor judgment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Multi-millionaire financier investigated for illegal sexual activity with minors. The subject of the federal investigation resolved by the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, later U.S. Secretary of Labor
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney who approved the Non-Prosecution Agreement with Epstein. A primary subject of the OPR investigation regarding his decision-making and oversight.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.role: U.S. Senator, Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Oversight
persons.context: Sent a letter to OPR in December 2018 requesting an investigation into possible misconduct by DOJ attorneys following the Miami Herald report.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Nominated Alexander Acosta to be Secretary of Labor in 2017.

persons.name: Ron DeSantis
persons.context: Announced in August 2019 that he directed the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to open an investigation into state authorities' conduct relating to Epstein.

persons.name: Julie K. Brown
persons.context: Miami Herald reporter who authored the November 2018 investigative report 'Perversion of Justice' that reignited public scrutiny of the Epstein case.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, was the principal government official responsible for approving the Non-Prosecution Agreement that resolved the federal investigation into Epstein.
Epstein deployed an extensive team of prominent attorneys who negotiated the NPA with the USAO and later tried to change its terms.
Acosta and USAO prosecutors engaged in meetings and communications with Epstein's team of attorneys to negotiate the NPA.
Senator Sasse requested the OPR investigation that scrutinized Acosta's conduct in the Epstein case.

events.title: Initial Police Complaint
events.description: Parents of a 14-year-old girl complained to Palm Beach Police that Epstein had paid her for a massage, initiating the local investigation.

events.title: State Grand Jury Indictment
events.description: A Palm Beach County grand jury indicted Epstein for felony solicitation of prostitution.

events.title: Draft Federal Indictment Prepared
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney submitted a draft 60-count federal indictment against Epstein to her supervisors.

events.title: USAO Offers State-Based Resolution
events.description: At a meeting with Epstein's attorneys, the USAO offered to end its investigation if Epstein pled guilty to state charges, served jail time, and registered as a sex offender.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: The NPA was signed, requiring Epstein to plead guilty to state charges, serve jail time, register as a sex offender, and provide a mechanism for victim restitution, in exchange for the USAO ending its federal investigation.

events.title: Epstein's State Guilty Plea
events.description: Epstein appeared in state court and pled guilty to state charges of solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution, as required by the NPA.

events.title: CVRA Lawsuit Filed
events.description: A victim filed an emergency petition in federal court alleging the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by not consulting victims before the NPA.

events.title: Miami Herald Investigation Published
events.description: Julie K. Brown's 'Perversion of Justice' report detailed the Epstein NPA, leading to public outrage and renewed scrutiny.

events.title: Court Finds CVRA Violation
events.description: A federal district court granted partial summary judgment to victims, ruling the government violated the CVRA by not advising victims about the NPA and misleading them.

events.title: SDNY Indicts Epstein
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York obtained a federal indictment charging Epstein with sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Acosta Resigns
events.description: Alexander Acosta submitted his resignation as U.S. Secretary of Labor following continued controversy over his role in the Epstein case.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanging in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan and was pronounced dead. The medical examiner ruled it a suicide.

locations: Florida Science Foundation, West Palm Beach
keyFacts: The OPR investigation concluded that the prosecutors, including Alexander Acosta, did not commit professional misconduct in negotiating the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, but that Acosta exercised 'poor judgment.'

The NPA required Epstein to plead guilty to state charges, serve 18 months in jail (he served less than 13), register as a sex offender, and provide a mechanism for victim restitution, in exchange for the federal government ending its investigation and agreeing not to prosecute Epstein or named co-conspirators.

Victims were not informed of or consulted about the NPA before it was signed, and letters sent to victims afterward described the case as 'under investigation,' which a federal court later found misled them.

The report details Epstein's efforts after the NPA was signed to invalidate it by appealing to senior DOJ officials, arguing the matter was a 'quintessentially state matter,' but the Deputy Attorney General declined to intervene in June 2008.
The OPR investigation was initiated following a December 2018 request from Senator Ben Sasse after the Miami Herald's November 2018 investigative report.
